#Text=Tirzah Firestone
#Text=Tirzah Firestone ( born May 27 , 1954 ) is a Jungian psychotherapist , author , and Jewish Renewal rabbi .
#Text=She is the founding rabbi of Congregation Nevei Kodesh , a Jewish Renewal synagogue in Boulder , Colorado , and is now Rabbi Emerita there . [ 1 ]
#Text=She was ordained by Rabbi Zalman Schachter Shalomi in 1992 and is a leader in the international Jewish Renewal Movement .

#Text=Widely known for her work on Jewish feminism and the modern applications of Jewish mystical wisdom , Firestone teaches nationally on Jewish ancestral healing and the common boundary between ancient Jewish heritage and modern psychology .
#Text=Firestone is an active Member of Aleph : Alliance for Jewish Renewal ( 1994 – present ) and the Ohalah Rabbinic Association ( 2003 – present ) .
#Text=She was the National Co-Chair of T'ruah : The Rabbinic Call for Human Rights ( 2009 – 2010 ) and is currently serving on the board of the Yesod Foundation ( 1997 – present ) .
#Text=Tirzah Firestone was raised in an Orthodox Jewish family in St. Louis , Missouri .
#Text=Firestone was the fifth of six children born to Sol and Kate Firestone .
#Text=She is the younger sister of Shulamith Firestone .
#Text=She went to Hebrew day schools through high school .

#Text=Firestone earned her Masters Degree in Holistic Counseling from Beacon College in 1982 ; and her doctorate in depth psychology from Pacifica Graduate Institute in Santa Barbara , California , in 2015 . [ 1 ]
#Text=After graduating , she spent an extended period living in Israel and working on Kibbutz Ma'ale Gilboa and Moshav Amirim .
#Text=She also apprenticed in Jerusalem with Rabanit Leah Sharabi , the wife of Kabbalist , Rabbi Mordechai Sharabi , who influenced her greatly .
#Text=In her memoir , Firestone tells the story of how her first husband inspired her return to Judaism by means of his own faith and love of Judaism .
#Text=Firestone remarried in 1999 to David Friedman .
#Text=Together they have three grown children .
#Text=Publications
#Text=Books
#Text=Wounds into Wisdom : Healing Intergenerational Jewish Trauma ( Monkfish Press , 2019 ) [ 2 ]
#Text=The Receiving : Reclaiming Jewish Women ’s Wisdom ( Harper San Francisco , 2003 ) [ 3 ]
#Text=With Roots in Heaven : One Woman 's Passionate Journey into the Heart of Her Faith ( Plume , 1999 ) [ 4 ]
#Text=Articles
#Text=" Intergenerational Trauma and the Patriarchy , " published in Tikkun Magazine , Spring 2019 .
#Text=" War and Peace : Intertwining Threads in the Jewish Tradition , " in The Warrior and the Pacifist : Competing Motifs in Buddhism , Judaism , Christianity , and Islam
#Text=Lester Kurtz , Ed . , Routledge Press , 2018 .
#Text=" Trauma Legacies in the Middle East " , published in Tikkun Magazine , 2014 , 29 ( 3 ) : 6-10. [ 5 ]
#Text=" The Jewish Cultural Complex , " published in Psychological Perspectives : A Quarterly Journal of Jungian Thought , Vol 57 , No 3 , August , 2014 . [ 6 ]
#Text=" At the Altar of Consciousness : The Individuation of God and Abraham " , published in Psychological Perspectives : A Quarterly Journal of Jungian Thought , Volume 56 , 2013 . [ 7 ]

#Text=“ Transforming Our Stories Through Midrash ” , in New Jewish Feminism : Probing the Past , Forging the Future , edited by Rabbi Elyse Goldstein , Jewish Lights Publishing , Woodstock , VT , 2009 .

#Text=“ Flatbread in Feeble Times ” , in The Women ’s Seder Sourcebook : Rituals and Readings for Use at the Passover Seder , Edited by Anisfeld , Mohr & Spector , Jewish Lights Publishing , Woodstock , VT , 2003 .
#Text=CDs
#Text=" Ashreynu ! ( How Lucky We Are ! )
